pullrequest.title: WIP: Boundary conditions evaluated at the midpoint

content.raw: Looks like there are a few more wires to be connected in the problem parser and pencil matrix construction.  These are both parts of the code that I'll be overhauling shortly for the parity basis, but if you feel like digging into it I can point out the particular sections that need to be changed (BC selection matrices), or I could probably get to it myself tomorrow and issue a pull request to your branch if that's easier.

These are both parts of the code that I'll be overhauling shortly for the parity basis, but if you feel like digging into it I can point out the particular sections that need to be changed (BC selection matrices), or I could probably get to it myself tomorrow and issue a pull request to your branch if that's easier.

pullrequest.title: WIP: Boundary conditions evaluated at the midpoint

content.raw: Yeah, I tried it out again on the cylindrical convection problem, and it crashed again (though in a different way) after five iterations.  I'm going to test it out on the gravity current problem (i.e., have the gravity current be in only half of the domain).  I'm a bit worried that the coefficient is zero in half of the modes -- doesn't that mean that half the modes don't have a second boundary condition?
content.html: Yeah, I tried it out again on the cylindrical convection problem, and it crashed again (though in a different way) after five iterations. I'm going to test it out on the gravity current problem (i.e., have the gravity current be in only half of the domain). I'm a bit worried that the coefficient is zero in half of the modes -- doesn't that mean that half the modes don't have a second boundary condition?

pullrequest.title: WIP: Boundary conditions evaluated at the midpoint

content.raw: Well for a given transverse mode, a BC is a single condition that constrains the whole Chebyshev series, not really a set of separate conditions on each Chebyshev mode. So as long as the resulting tau system is non-singular (i.e. the chosen BC essentially fixes the mode left undetermined by the truncated equation set), it's okay if the BC isn't influenced by every mode.  The integral BC vector, for instance, also has zeros for all the same (odd) modes.
content.html: Well for a given transverse mode, a BC is a single condition that constrains the whole Chebyshev series, not really a set of separate conditions on each Chebyshev mode. So as long as the resulting tau system is non-singular (i.e. the chosen BC essentially fixes the mode left undetermined by the truncated equation set), it's okay if the BC isn't influenced by every mode. The integral BC vector, for instance, also has zeros for all the same (odd) modes.

content.raw: I tried running the gravity current problem, but setting the boundary conditions at the bottom and middle of the domain instead of top and bottom.  It crashed after five iterations.  So it seems that something is still wrong?
